page.title: 05MORTE POINT
page.content: This tongue of land stretches into the sea with Woolacombe on one side and Lee and Ilfracombe on the other. Cromlechs and other ancient relics link us with countless human beings who have enjoyed this lovely place from time immemorial. A stone erected on the highest point remembers the men of Mortehoe who kept watch here during the last war. It is possible to walk on the Point for hours and still not explore all the many paths which climb and dip over hilly, rocky terrain. Throughout the year flowers greet us - violets, primroses, bluebells, wild roses, heather, seapinks, gorse, and many others. Seabirds weave patterns overhead, and seals sport themselves on the rocks. The National Coastal Footpath traverses the entire Point. To stand precariously on the rocky tip surveying the Morte Stone, is awesome.
